revision.text:
{{infobox Organization |name = ProEnglish |image = Proenglishlogo.jpg |abbreviation = |motto = |formation = 1994 |type = |headquarters = 20 F Street NW, 7th Floor |location = [[Washington, D.C.]] |leader_title = Executive Director |leader_name = Stephen D. Guschov |website = {{official URL}} }} '''ProEnglish''' is an American [[Nonprofit organization|nonprofit]] organization that [[English-only movement|advocates making English the official language]] of government operations at all levels of government in the United States.<ref name="Maceri">Domenico Maceri, [https://www.nytimes.com/2003/06/24/opinion/multilingualism-americans-are-embracing-spanish.html Multilingualism: Americans are embracing Spanish] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170823030415/http://www.nytimes.com/2003/06/24/opinion/multilingualism-americans-are-embracing-spanish.html |date=2017-08-23 }}, ''International Herald Tribune'' (June 24, 2003).</ref> The group supports making English the only [[official language]] of the [[United States]].<ref name="Jordan">Miriam Jordan, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB113141835014390848 Testing 'English Only' Rules: Employers Who Require Workers to Speak English Can Face Discrimination Suits] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170308222455/https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB113141835014390848 |date=2017-03-08 }}, ''Wall Street Journal'' (November 8, 2005).</ref> It is organized as a self-governing project of US Inc., a 501(c)(3) educational foundation in Petoskey MI, concerned with immigration, assimilation, and conservation issues.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://usinc.org/about-us/ |title={title} |access-date=2018-03-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180620203734/https://usinc.org/about-us/ |archive-date=2018-06-20 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> The group has also campaigned against immigration reform and [[bilingual education]].
The [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] (SPLC) and [[Anti-Defamation League]], which track extremist groups in the United States, identify the group as an anti-immigrant group.<ref name="SPLCAug2015">[https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2015/08/27/anti-immigrant-group-proenglish-fails-english-only-effort-maryland Anti-Immigrant Group ProEnglish Fails With English-Only Effort in Maryland] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170309060955/https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2015/08/27/anti-immigrant-group-proenglish-fails-english-only-effort-maryland |date=2017-03-09 }}, ''Hatewatch'', [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] (August 27, 2015).</ref><ref name="Segal">Oren Segal, [https://www.adl.org/blog/proenglish-attacks-super-bowl-ad-promoting-americas-diversity ProEnglish Attacks Super Bowl Ad Promoting America's Diversity] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170308220910/https://www.adl.org/blog/proenglish-attacks-super-bowl-ad-promoting-americas-diversity |date=2017-03-08 }}, [[Anti-Defamation League]] (February 5, 2014).</ref> The SPLC [[List of organizations designated by the Southern Poverty Law Center as hate groups|designated the organization]] as a [[hate group]].<ref name="immigrant">{{cite web|url=http://www.splcenter.org/get-informed/intelligence-files/ideology/anti-immigrant/active_hate_groups|title=Active Anti-Immigrant Groups|publisher=Southern Poverty Law Center|accessdate=July 9, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714140546/http://www.splcenter.org/get-informed/intelligence-files/ideology/anti-immigrant/active_hate_groups|archive-date=2014-07-14|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref><ref name="2015Report">[https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/intelligence-report/2016/active-hate-groups-united-states-2015 Active Hate Groups in the United States in 2015] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170315164817/https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/intelligence-report/2016/active-hate-groups-united-states-2015 |date=2017-03-15 }}, Southern Poverty Law Center (February 4, 2016).</ref><ref name="2016Report">[https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/intelligence-report/2017/active-hate-groups-2016 Active Hate Groups 2016] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170314181757/https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/intelligence-report/2017/active-hate-groups-2016 |date=2017-03-14 }}, ''Intelligence Report'' (February 15, 2017).</ref>
==Founding and leadership== The group was founded in 1994 as '''English Language Advocates'''.<ref name="Ziegler-McPherson">Christina Ziegler-McPherson, "English Only Groups" in ''Anti-Immigration in the United States: A Historical Encyclopedia'' (Vol. 1: ed. Kathleen R. Arnold: Greenwood, 2011), p. 182.</ref>, by [[John Tanton]], M.D., a Petoskey, Michigan eye surgeon and a leading figure in the national immigration reform movement, along with three former board members of [[U.S. English (organization)|U.S. English]] who had resigned to protest that organization’s decision not to defend an Arizona official English law it had sponsored.<ref name="Salomone">Rosemary C. Salomone, ''True American'' ([[Harvard University Press]], 2010), p. 148.</ref> Tanton co-founded US English in 1983 with U.S. Senator [[S.I. Hayakawa]] of California, but had resigned from it earlier following the disclosure of a joke deemed racially insensitive in an internal memo he had written).<ref name="SPLCAug2015"/> The organization is part of Tanton's broader "loose-knit" network of anti-immigration organizations; others include [[Californians for Population Stabilization]], the [[Center for Immigration Studies]], [[NumbersUSA]], and [[Social Contract Press]].<ref>[https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/intelligence-report/2015/john-tantons-network Jonh Tanton's Network] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170309060821/https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/intelligence-report/2015/john-tantons-network |date=2017-03-09 }}, ''Intelligence Report'', [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] (2015).</ref> As of 2015{{When|date=October 2018}}, ProEnglish "is one of the few remaining groups in Tanton's network in which he remains actively involved."<ref name="SPLCAug2015"/> ProEnglish is a project of '''US Inc.''', a Petoskey, Michigan-based 501(c)(3) group that is also part of the Tanton network.<ref>[http://usinc.org/about-us/ About Us] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180620203734/https://usinc.org/about-us/ |date=2018-06-20 }}, US Inc.</ref>
The group was originally based in [[Arlington, Virginia]],<ref name="Ziegler-McPherson"/> where it shared office space with NumbersUSA.<ref>Brian Bennett & Joseph Tanfani, [http://articles.latimes.com/2013/jul/13/nation/la-na-immigration-opponents-20130714 Group opposing immigration bill plans full-scale campaign on House] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170309061006/http://articles.latimes.com/2013/jul/13/nation/la-na-immigration-opponents-20130714 |date=2017-03-09 }}, ''Los Angeles Times'' (July 13, 2013).</ref> Its headquarters are now located in [[Washington, D.C.]]<ref name="Segal"/> In 2010 ELA changed its name to ProEnglish. Robert D. Park was the first chair of the group.<ref>Sandra Del Valle, ''Language Rights and the Law in the United States: Finding Our Voices'' (Multilingual Matters, 2003), p. 79.</ref> He was succeeded by Rosalie Pedalino Porter, EdD, a naturalized U.S. citizen and nationally recognized authority on the failures of bilingual education.<ref>[https://judiciary.house.gov/_files/hearings/Hearings%202012/Porter%2008022012.pdf Testimony of Rosalie Pedalino Porter, Ed.D, Chairwoman of the Board of Directors, ProEnglish] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170727074113/https://judiciary.house.gov/_files/hearings/Hearings%202012/Porter%2008022012.pdf |date=2017-07-27 }}, Before the United States House of Representatives Committee on the JHudiciary, Subcommittee on the Constituition, Regarding H.R. 997, the "English Language Unity Act" (August 2, 2012).</ref>
The group's former executive directors are K.C. McAlpin<ref name="Jordan"/> and Robert "Bob" Vandervoort.<ref name="SPLCAug2015"/><ref name="Sussman">[[Robert W. Sussman]], ''The Myth of Race: The Troubling Persistence of an Unscientific Idea'' (Harvard University Press, 2014), p. 299.</ref> In 2016, Sam Pimm, former executive director of [[Young Americans for Freedom]] and former executive director of a pro-[[Ben Carson]] [[super PAC]], became executive director of the group.<ref>[https://proenglish.org/2016/06/02/the-proenglish-board-of-directors-welcomes-new-executive-director-sam-pimm/ ProEnglish Board of Directors Welcomes New Executive Director Sam Pimm] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170308223641/https://proenglish.org/2016/06/02/the-proenglish-board-of-directors-welcomes-new-executive-director-sam-pimm/ |date=2017-03-08 }} (press release), ProEnglish (June 2, 2016).</ref> Subsequently, Stephen D. Guschov, a lawyer who formerly worked at [[Liberty Counsel]], because executive director of the group.<ref>[https://proenglish.org/meet-the-staff/ Meet the staff] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171228054220/https://proenglish.org/meet-the-staff/ |date=2017-12-28 }}, ProEnglish (last accessed December 27, 2017).</ref>
==Beliefs and activities== [[File:USA states english official language.PNG|thumb|alt=Map of United States Official Language Status By State|Map of US official language status by state before 2016. Blue: English declared the official language; light-blue: 2 official languages, including English; gray: no official language specified.]] ProEnglish has been a major part of the "English-as-official-language movement."<ref name="Rosenwald">Michael S. Rosenwald, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/rosenwald-md/post/frederick-county-makes-english-its-official-language/2012/02/22/gIQAbECLTR_blog.html Frederick County makes English its official language] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170308222103/https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/rosenwald-md/post/frederick-county-makes-english-its-official-language/2012/02/22/gIQAbECLTR_blog.html |date=2017-03-08 }}, ''Washington Post'' (February 22, 2012).</ref> The group also has opposed comprehensive immigration reform.<ref name="Rubin">[[Jennifer Rubin (journalist)|Jennifer Rubin]], [https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/right-turn/wp/2013/05/14/gang-of-eight-moves-forward/ Gang of Eight moves forward] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170308220149/https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/right-turn/wp/2013/05/14/gang-of-eight-moves-forward/ |date=2017-03-08 }}, ''Washington Post'' (May 14, 2013).</ref> The chief purpose of the organization at the time of its founding was to defend the [[Arizona]] "Official English" ballot initiative, which was adopted in 1988, overturned by the [[Arizona Supreme Court]] in 1998, and re-enacted in revised form by Arizona voters in 2006.<ref name="Salomone"/> The group has also supported federal English-only legislation, specifically the [[English Language Unity Act]].<ref>[https://judiciary.house.gov/_files/hearings/Hearings%202012/Porter%2008022012.pdf Rosalie Pedalino Porter, Chairwoman of the Board of Directors, ProEnglish] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170727074113/https://judiciary.house.gov/_files/hearings/Hearings%202012/Porter%2008022012.pdf |date=2017-07-27 }}, Testimony Before the [[United States House Judiciary Subcommittee on the Constitution]] (August 2, 2012).</ref> In addition to seeking the enactment of laws and policies declaring English to be the official language, ProEnglish "seeks to end [[bilingual education]], repeal federal mandates for the translation of government documents and voting ballots in languages other than English."<ref name="Ziegler-McPherson"/> ProEnglish also opposes [[Puerto Rican statehood]] unless [[Puerto Rico]] were to adopt English as its official language.<ref name="Ziegler-McPherson"/>
The group's reported ties to the [[white nationalist]] movement have drawn scrutiny.<ref name="Rubin"/><ref name="Evans">Desiree Evans, [https://www.facingsouth.org/2009/01/largest-funder-of-nashvilles-failed-english-only-amendment-had-links-to-hate-groups.html Largest funder of Nashville's failed English-only amendment had links to hate groups] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170308224115/https://www.facingsouth.org/2009/01/largest-funder-of-nashvilles-failed-english-only-amendment-had-links-to-hate-groups.html |date=2017-03-08 }}, ''Facing South'', [[Institute for Southern Studies]] (January 27, 2009).</ref> The [[Anti-Defamation League]] wrote in 2014 that the group had a "nativist agenda and xenophobic origins and ties."<ref name="Segal"/> Robert Vandervoort of Illinois, the former executive director of ProEnglish, was head of the Chicagoland Friends of ''[[American Renaissance (magazine)|American Renaissance]]'', the racist magazine led by [[Jared Taylor]] that serves as an outlet for white nationalist ideology.<ref name="Sussman"/> In 2012, ProEnglish hosted a panel discussion at the [[Conservative Political Action Conference]] (CPAC) on "The Failure of Multiculturalism," on which one of the panelists was [[VDARE]] founder [[Peter Brimelow]].<ref>Patrick Caldwell, [http://prospect.org/article/white-nationalists-agree-multiculturalism-bad White Nationalists Agree: Multiculturalism Is Bad] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170308221228/http://prospect.org/article/white-nationalists-agree-multiculturalism-bad |date=2017-03-08 }}, ''The American Prospect'' (February 9, 2012).</ref> The [[Southern Poverty Law Center]], which tracks extremist groups in the United States, [[List of organizations designated by the Southern Poverty Law Center as hate groups|designated the group]] as a [[hate group]] in its 2014, 2015, and 2016 annual reports.<ref name="immigrant"/><ref name="2015Report"/><ref name="2016Report"/> The group has dismissed such criticism.<ref name="Alaimo2013">Carol Ann Alaimo, [http://tucson.com/news/local/education/student-suit-vs-pima-college-draws-support-of-proenglish-group/article_2b22c3b0-1148-58c7-a116-59c8551f676f.html Student suit vs. Pima College draws support of ProEnglish group] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170308232959/http://tucson.com/news/local/education/student-suit-vs-pima-college-draws-support-of-proenglish-group/article_2b22c3b0-1148-58c7-a116-59c8551f676f.html |date=2017-03-08 }}, ''Arizona Daily Star'' (July 14, 2013).</ref>
ProEnglish was a major backer of the unsuccessful 2009 [[Nashville Charter Amendment 1]], a local "English First" [[Ballot question|ballot referendum]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], which would have generally required government communication and publications to be printed in English only.<ref name="Cousins">Juanita Cousins, [http://archive.azcentral.com/news/articles/2009/01/22/20090122nashville.html Nashville voters reject 'English First' proposal] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170308223645/http://archive.azcentral.com/news/articles/2009/01/22/20090122nashville.html |date=2017-03-08 }}, Associated Press (January 22, 2009).</ref> ProEnglish donated $82,500, about 92% of the total amount raised by the referendum's supporters.<ref name="Evans"/> The referendum was rejected by Nashville voters.<ref name="Evans"/><ref name="Cousins"/> In 2012, ProEnglish was the leading force behind a successful effort to make English the official language of [[Frederick County, Maryland]]; the county enacted an ordinance closely based on one drafted by the group.<ref name="Rosenwald"/> However, in 2015, the country repealed the ordinance, marking a defeat for the organization.<ref name="SPLCAug2015"/>
ProEnglish has also worked for the adoption of official English laws at the local level, most notably in [[Hazleton, Pennsylvania]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://judiciary.house.gov/_files/hearings/Hearings%202012/Porter%2008022012.pdf |title={title} |access-date=2017-12-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170727074113/https://judiciary.house.gov/_files/hearings/Hearings%202012/Porter%2008022012.pdf |archive-date=2017-07-27 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
In 2013, ProEnglish vocally opposed the [[Border Security, Economic Opportunity, and Immigration Modernization Act of 2013|comprehensive immigration reform bill]] sponsored by the "[[Gang of Eight (immigration)|Gang of Eight]]," a bipartisan group of U.S. senators. ProEnglish carried out a radio ad campaign against U.S. Senator [[Lindsey Graham]], who was part of the Gang of Eight.<ref name="Rubin"/>
In 2014, ProEnglish criticized [[The Coca-Cola Company]] for airing a [[Super Bowl commercials|Super Bowl commercial]] that showed people of different ethnicities singing "[[America, the Beautiful]]" in a variety of languages. ProEnglish condemned Coca-Cola (saying the ad fostered "disunity") and urged its supporters to contact the company to express opposition.<ref name="Segal"/>
In 2017, ProEnglish endorsed the section of the Reforming American Immigration for a Strong Economy (RAISE) Act that calls for a merit-based legal immigration system in which applicants would get points for speaking English.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://proenglish.org/2017/08/11/rep-dana-rohrabacher-co-sponsors-hr-997/ |title={title} |access-date=2017-12-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171204223004/https://proenglish.org/2017/08/11/rep-dana-rohrabacher-co-sponsors-hr-997/ |archive-date=2017-12-04 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-bill/997 |title={title} |access-date=2017-12-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170803050216/https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-bill/997 |archive-date=2017-08-03 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>In 2017, ProEnglish endorsed the section of the Reforming American Immigration for a Strong Economy (RAISE) Act that calls for a merit-based legal immigration system in which applicants would get points for speaking English.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://proenglish.org/2017/08/11/rep-dana-rohrabacher-co-sponsors-hr-997/ |title={title} |access-date=2017-12-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171204223004/https://proenglish.org/2017/08/11/rep-dana-rohrabacher-co-sponsors-hr-997/ |archive-date=2017-12-04 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-bill/997 |title={title} |access-date=2017-12-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170803050216/https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-bill/997 |archive-date=2017-08-03 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
===Litigation history=== In 2005, ProEnglish was helping pay the legal fees of at least two employers who had an "English-only rule" requiring employees to speak only English while on the job.<ref name="Jordan"/> ProEnglish paid the legal fees of Terri Bennett, a former nursing student at [[Pima Community College]] (PCC) in [[Tucson, Arizona]], "who claimed she was wrongly suspended for complaining when fellow students spoke Spanish to one another in class."<ref name="Alaimo2015">Carol Ann Alaimo, [http://tucson.com/news/local/education/ex-student-who-sued-pima-college-must-pay-k/article_5f157fed-024d-59da-9731-6e0476dcffe1.html Ex-student who sued Pima College must pay $111K] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151017232059/http://tucson.com/news/local/education/ex-student-who-sued-pima-college-must-pay-k/article_5f157fed-024d-59da-9731-6e0476dcffe1.html |date=2015-10-17 }}, ''[[Arizona Daily Star]]'' (October 15, 2015).</ref><ref name="Alaimo2013"/> At trial, the evidence showed that Bennett had called [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Hispanic]] classmates "spics, beaners and illegals" and the [[Spanish language]] "gibberish."<ref name="Alaimo2015"/> A jury unanimously rejected the Bennett's claims, and in 2015 ordered her to pay $111,000 in attorney's fees to PCC.<ref name="Alaimo2015"/>
In 2008, ProEnglish, along with the [[Pacific Legal Foundation]], filed a lawsuit in [[United States federal court|federal court]] challenging 2004 [[U.S. Department of Health and Human Service]] regulations that required federally funded healthcare providers to provide translation services for patients who do not speak English. The challengers claimed that the regulations were an "illegal intrusion" on healthcare providers. U.S. District Judge [[Barry Ted Moskowitz]] dismissed the suit in 2009.<ref>[http://khn.org/morning-breakout/dr00028586/ Federal Judge Dismisses Lawsuit Filed by ProEnglish Over HHS Guidelines on Translation Services for Patients] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170308223447/http://khn.org/morning-breakout/dr00028586/ |date=2017-03-08 }}, Kaiser Health News (June 11, 2009).</ref>
In ''EEOC v. Kidmans'' (2005), ProEnglish helped fund the litigation costs of a small [[drive-in restaurant]] in [[Page, Arizona]], that was sued by the [[Equal Employment Opportunity Commission]] after it refused to retract an English-on-the-job rule. The restaurant said that the rule was adopted to stop "trash talking" in the [[Navajo language]] among employees, most of whom are [[Navajo people|Navajo]].<ref>[http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fsb/fsb_archive/2003/05/01/343415/ Fighting Words How a tiny drive-in restaurant in Arizona became the center of a bitter battle over English-only rules in the workplace] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201045327/http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fsb/fsb_archive/2003/05/01/343415/ |date=2017-12-01 }}, CNN Money (May 1, 2003).</ref> The EEOC and the restaurant owners ultimately negotiated a settlement, in which the employees "may require employees to speak English while dealing with the public, but not at other times."<ref>Dennis Barron, [https://blogs.illinois.edu/view/25/2910 Not just freedom fries at this English-only drive-in?] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180620181101/https://blogs.illinois.edu/view/25/2910 |date=2018-06-20 }}, ''The Web of Language'' (November 23, 2007).</ref>
==Support for Structured English Immersion== ProEnglish opposes the method of teaching English language learning (ELL) students that teaches them basic courses in their native language while they learn English, known as ‘bilingual education,’ as a failed 40-year experiment. Instead, it favors the method known as ‘structured English immersion,’ in which ELLs are taught in English while being given supplemental learning assistance on the side.
Accordingly, it backed successful citizen initiative that ended bilingual education programs in California (1998), Arizona (2000), and Massachusetts (2002), as well as one unsuccessful such citizen’s initiative in Colorado (2002). ProEnglish Chair Dr. Rosalie Porter co-chaired the English for the Children initiative in Massachusetts that passed with 68 percent of the vote. Much research comparing students in bilingual programs to students in structured English immersion consistently shows far better results in English immersion classes. {{cite book |last= Imhoff|first= Gary|date= 1990|title= Learning In Two Languages|url= |location= |publisher= |page= |isbn= |author-link= }}
==Repealing Executive Order 13166== [[Executive Order 13166]], also known as “Improving Access to Services for Persons with Limited English Proficiency,” states that any entity receiving federal funds must provide translations or interpreters for the services it provides in the language spoken by persons likely to use those services. It states that failure to do so is likely to constitute “discrimination on the basis of national origin” as prohibited by Title VI of the 1964 Civil Rights law.
An [[Executive order (United States)|executive order]] signed by President [[Bill Clinton]] on August 11, 2000, the order directed all federal agencies to draft plans to “improve access to federally conducted or federally assisted programs for persons who, as a result of national origin, are limited in their English proficiency.” The mandate also applies to all state and local government agencies and their subdivisions, and government contractors that receive federal funds.<ref name="Maceri"/>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
== External links == * {{official website}}
[[Category:501(c)(3) nonprofit organizations]] [[Category:American nationalism| ]] [[Category:Charities based in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:English-only movement in the United States]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1994]] [[Category:Political and economic think tanks]]

contributor.username: Me, Myself, and I are Here

revision.text:
'''Referring expression generation''' ('''REG''') is the subtask of [[natural language generation]] (NLG) that received most scholarly attention. While NLG is concerned with the conversion of non-linguistic information into natural language, '''REG''' focuses only on the creation of [[referring expression]]s (noun phrases) that identify specific entities called ''targets''.
This task can be split into two sections. The ''content selection'' part determines which set of properties distinguish the intended target and the ''linguistic realization'' part defines how these properties are translated into natural language. A variety of algorithms have been developed in the NLG community to generate different types of referring expressions.
==Types of referring expressions== A [[referring expression]] (RE), in linguistics, is any [[noun phrase]], or surrogate for a noun phrase, whose function in discourse is to ''identify'' some individual object (thing, being, event...) The [[technical terminology]] for ''identify'' differs a great deal from one school of linguistics to another. The most widespread term is probably ''refer'', and a thing identified is a ''referent'', as for example in the work of [[John Lyons (linguist)|John Lyons]]. In linguistics, the study of reference relations belongs to [[pragmatics]], the study of language use, though it is also a matter of great interest to philosophers, especially those wishing to understand the nature of [[knowledge]], [[perception]] and [[cognition]] more generally.
Various devices can be used for reference: [[determiner]]s, [[pronoun]]s, [[proper name]]s... Reference relations can be of different kinds; referents can be in a "real" or imaginary world, in discourse itself, and they may be singular, plural, or collective.
===Pronouns=== The simplest type of referring expressions are [[pronouns|pronoun]] such as ''he'' and ''it''. The linguistics and natural language processing communities have developed various models for predicting anaphor referents, such as centering theory,<ref name="Poesio et al.">M Poesio, R Stevenson, B di Eugenio, J Hitzeman (2004). Centering: A Parametric Theory and Its Instantiations. ''Computational Linguistics'' 30:309-363 [http://www.aclweb.org/anthology/J04-3003.pdf]</ref> and ideally referring-expression generation would be based on such models. However most NLG systems use much simpler algorithms, for example using a pronoun if the referent was mentioned in the previous sentence (or sentential clause), and no other entity of the same gender was mentioned in this sentence.
===Definite noun phrases=== There has been a considerable amount of research on generating definite noun phrases, such as ''the big red book''. Much of this builds on the model proposed by Dale and Reiter.<ref name="Dale&Reiter"/> This has been extended in various ways, for example Krahmer ''et al.''<ref name="Krahmer,Erk,Verleg">E Krahmer, S van Erk, A Verleg (2003). Graph-Based Generation of Referring Expressions. Computational Linguistics 23:53-72 [http://www.aclweb.org/anthology/J03-1003.pdf]</ref> present a graph-theoretic model of definite NP generation with many nice properties. In recent years a shared-task event has compared different algorithms for definite NP generation, using the TUNA<ref>[https://www.abdn.ac.uk/ncs/departments/computing-science/corpus-496.php]</ref> corpus.
===Spatial and temporal reference=== Recently there has been more research on generating referring expressions for time and space. Such references tend to be imprecise (what is the exact meaning of ''tonight''?), and also to be interpreted in different ways by different people.<ref>E Reiter, S Sripada, J Hunter, J Yu, and I Davy (2005). Choosing Words in Computer-Generated Weather Forecasts. ''Artificial Intelligence'' 167:137-169.</ref> Hence it may be necessary to explicitly reason about false positive vs false negative tradeoffs, and even calculate the utility of different possible referring expressions in a particular task context.<ref name="Turner et al.">R Turner, Y Sripada, E Reiter (2009) Generating Approximate Geographic Descriptions. ''Proceedings of the 12th European Workshop on Natural Language Generation (ENLG)'', pages 42–49, Athens. [http://www.aclweb.org/anthology/W09-0607.pdf]</ref>
===Criteria for good expressions=== Ideally, a good referring expression should satisfy a number of criteria: * ''Referential success'': It should unambiguously identify the referent to the reader. * ''Ease of comprehension'': The reader should be able to quickly read and understand it. * ''Computational complexity'': The generation algorithm should be fast * ''No false inferences'': The expression should not confuse or mislead the reader by suggesting false [[implicature]]s or other pragmatic inferences. For example, a reader may be confused if he is told ''Sit by the brown wooden table'' in a context where there is only one table.<ref name="Dale&Reiter">R Dale, E Reiter (1995). Computational interpretations of the Gricean maxims in the generation of referring expressions. ''Cognitive Science'', 18:233–263.</ref>
==History==
===Pre-2000 era=== REG goes back to the early days of NLG. One of the first approaches was done by Winograd<ref>T Winograd (1972). Understanding Natural Language. ''Academic Press'', New York. Section 8.3.3, Naming Objects and Events</ref> in 1972 who developed an "[[incremental algorithm|incremental]]" REG algorithm for his [[SHRDLU]] program. Afterwards researchers started to model the human abilities to create referring expressions in the 1980s. This new approach to the topic was influenced by the researchers Appelt and Kronfeld who created the programs KAMP and BERTRAND<ref name="Appelt">D Appelt (1985). Planning English referring expressions. ''Artificial Intelligence'', 26:1–33.</ref><ref name="Appelt&Kronfeld">D Appelt, A Kronfeld (1987). A computational model of referring. ''In Proceedings of the 10th International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence (IJCAI)'', pages 640–647, Milan.</ref><ref>A Kronfeld (1990). Reference and Computation: An Essay in Applied Philosophy of Language. ''Cambridge University Press'', Cambridge.</ref> and considered referring expressions as parts of bigger speech acts.
Some of their most interesting findings were the fact that referring expressions can be used to add information beyond the identification of the referent<ref name="Appelt&Kronfeld" /> as well as the influence of communicative context and the [[Gricean maxim]]s on referring expressions.<ref name="Appelt" /> Furthermore, its skepticism concerning the naturalness of minimal descriptions made Appelt and Kronfeld's research a foundation of later work on REG.
The search for simple, well-defined problems changed the direction of research in the early 1990s. This new approach was led by Dale and Reiter who stressed the identification of the referent as the central goal.<ref name="Dale1989">R Dale (1989). Cooking up referring expressions. ''In Proceedings of the 27th Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics (ACL)'', pages 68–75.</ref><ref name="Dale1992">R Dale (1992). Generating Referring Expressions: Constructing Descriptions in a Domain of Objects and Processes. ''TheMIT Press'', Cambridge, MA.</ref><ref>E Reiter (1990). The computational complexity of avoiding conversational implicatures. ''In Proceedings of the 28th Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics (ACL)'', pages 97–104, Pittsburgh, PA.</ref><ref>E Reiter, R Dale (1992). A fast algorithm for the generation of referring expressions. ''In Proceedings of the 14th International Conference on Computational Linguistics (COLING)'', pages 232–238, Nantes.</ref> Like Appelt<ref name="Appelt" /> they discuss the connection between the [[Gricean maxim]]s and referring expressions in their culminant paper<ref name="Dale&Reiter"/> in which they also propose a formal [[#Problem definition|problem definition]]. Furthermore, Reiter and Dale discuss the [[#Full Brevity|Full Brevity]] and [[#Greedy Heuristics|Greedy Heuristics]] algorithms as well as their [[#Incremental Algorithm|Incremental Algorithm]](IA) which became one of the most important algorithms in REG. <ref group="note" name="Krahmer&van Deemter">This section is an excerpt of the following paper. For more details see: E Krahmer, K van Deemter (2012). Computational Generation of Referring Expressions: A Survey. ''Computational Linguistics'' 38:173-218 [https://aclweb.org/anthology/J/J12/J12-1006.pdf]</ref>
===Later developments=== After 2000 the research began to lift some of the simplifying assumptions, that had been made in early REG research in order to create more simple algorithms. Different research groups concentrated on different limitations creating several expanded algorithms. Often these extend the IA in a single perspective for example in relation to:
* ''Reference to Sets'' like "the t-shirt wearers" or "the green apples and the banana on the left"<ref>H Horacek (2004). On referring to sets of objects naturally. ''Proceedings of the 3rd International Conference on Natural Language Generation (INLG)'', pages 70–79, Brockenhurst.</ref><ref>A Gatt, K van Deemter (2007). Lexical choice and conceptual perspective in the generation of plural referring expressions. ''Journal of Logic, Language and Information'', 16:423–443.</ref><ref>I H Khan, K van Deemter, G Ritchie (2008). Generation of referring expressions: Managing structural ambiguities. ''Proceedings of the 22nd International Conference on Computational Linguistics (COLING)'', pages 433–440, Manchester.</ref><ref>M Stone (2000). On identifying sets. ''Proceedings of the 1st International Conference on Natural Language Generation (INLG)'', pages 116–123, Mitzpe Ramon.</ref> * ''Relational Descriptions'' like "the cup on the table" or "the woman who has three children"<ref name="Dale&Haddock">R Dale, N Haddock (1991). Generating referring expressions involving relations. ''Proceedings of the 5th Conference of the European Chapter of the Association of Computational Linguists (EACL)'', pages 161–166, Berlin.</ref><ref>E Krahmer, M Theune (2002). Efficient context-sensitive generation of descriptions in context. In K van Deemter, R Kibble, editors, ''Information Sharing: Givenness and Newness in Language Processing''. CSLI Publications, Stanford, CA, pages 223–264.</ref><ref name="Viethen&Dale">J Viethen, R Dale (2008). The use of spatial relations in referring expressions. ''Proceedings of the 5th International Natural Language Generation Conference (INLG)'', pages 59–67, Salt Fork, OH.</ref><ref>Y Ren, K van Deemter, J Pan (2010). Charting the potential of Description Logic for the generation of referring expressions. ''Proceedings of the 6th International Natural Language Generation Conference (INLG)'', pages 115–124, Dublin.</ref><ref name="Krahmer,Goudbeek,Theune">E Krahmer, M Goudbeek, M Theune (2014). Referring Expression Generation in Interaction: A Graph-based perspective. ''A Stent, S Bangalore (eds.), Natural Language Generation in Interactive Systems''. Cambridge University Press.</ref> * ''Context Dependency'', ''Vagueness'' and ''Gradeability'' include statements like "the older man" or "the car on the left" which are often unclear without a context<ref name="Turner et al."/><ref>K van Deemter (2006). Generating referring expressions that involve gradable properties. ''Computational Linguistics'', 32(2):195–222.</ref><ref>H Horacek (2005). Generating referential descriptions under conditions of uncertainty. ''Proceedings of the 10th European Workshop on Natural Language Generation (ENLG)'', pages 58–67, Aberdeen.</ref> * ''Salience'' and ''Generation of Pronouns'' are highly discourse dependent making for example "she" a reference to "the (most salient) female person"<ref>R Passonneau (1996). Using centering to relax Gricean informational constraints on discourse anaphoric noun phrases. ''Language and Speech'', 39:229–264.</ref><ref>P W Jordan (2000). Intentional Influences on Object Redescriptions in Dialogue: Evidence from an Empirical Study. Ph.D. thesis, University of Pittsburgh.</ref><ref>E Hajičová (1993). ''Issues of Sentence Structure and Discourse Patterns—Theoretical and Computational Linguistics, Vol. 2''. Charles University, Prague.</ref><ref>B J Grosz, A K Joshi, S Weinstein (1995). Centering: A framework for modeling the local coherence of discourse. ''Computational Linguistics'', 21:203–225.</ref><ref>D DeVault, C Rich, C L Sidner (2004). Natural language generation and discourse context: Computing distractor sets from the focus stack. ''Proceedings of the 17th International Meeting of the Florida Artificial Intelligence Research Society (FLAIRS)'', Miami Beach, FL.</ref><ref>A Siddharthan, A Copestake (2004). Generating referring expressions in open domains. ''Proceedings of the 42nd Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics (ACL)'', pages 407–414, Barcelona.</ref><ref>I Paraboni, K van Deemter, J Masthoff (2007). Generating referring expressions: Making referents easy to identity. ''Computational Linguistics'', 33:229–254.</ref>
Many simplifying assumptions are still in place or have just begun to be worked on. Also a combination of the different extensions has yet to be done and is called a "non-trivial enterprise" by Krahmer and van Deemter.<ref name="Krahmer&van Deemter">E Krahmer, K van Deemter (2012). Computational Generation of Referring Expressions: A Survey. ''Computational Linguistics'' 38:173-218 [https://aclweb.org/anthology/J/J12/J12-1006.pdf]</ref>
Another important change after 2000 was the increasing use of [[#Evaluation of REG systems|empirical studies]] in order to evaluate algorithms. This development took place due to the emergence of transparent [[#Corpus-based Evaluation|corpora]]. Although there are still discussions about what the best evaluation metrics are, the use of experimental evaluation has already led to a better comparability of algorithms, a discussion about the goals of REG and more task-oriented research.
Furthermore, research has extended its range to related topics such as the choice of ''[[Knowledge representation and reasoning|Knowledge Representation]](KR) Frameworks''. In this area the main question, which KR framework is most suitable for the use in REG remains open. The answer to this question depends on how well descriptions can be expressed or found. A lot of the potential of KR frameworks has been left unused so far.
Some of the different approaches are the usage of:
* ''[[Graph search]]'' which treats relations between targets in the same way as properties.<ref name="Krahmer,Erk,Verleg"/><ref name="Viethen&Dale"/><ref name="Krahmer,Goudbeek,Theune"/><ref>E Krahmer, M Theune, J Viethen, I Hendrickx (2008). Graph: The costs of redundancy in referring expressions. ''Proceedings of the International Conference on Natural Language Generation (INLG)'', pages 227–229, Salt Fork, OH.</ref><ref>K van Deemter, E Krahmer (2007). Graphs and Booleans: On the generation of referring expressions. In H Bunt, R Muskens, editors, ''Computing Meaning, Volume 3. Studies in Linguistics and Philosophy''. Springer Publishers, Berlin, pages 397–422.</ref> * ''[[Constraint satisfaction problem|Constraint Satisfaction]]'' which allows for a separation between problem specification and the implementation.<ref name="Dale&Haddock"/><ref>C Gardent (2002). Generating minimal definite descriptions. ''Proceedings of the 40th Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics (ACL)'', pages 96–103, Philadelphia, PA.</ref> * ''Modern Knowledge Representation'' which offers [[logical inference]] in for example [[Description Logic]] or [[Conceptual Graph]]s.<ref>M Croitoru, K van Deemter (2007). A conceptual graph approach to the generation of referring expressions. ''Proceedings of the 20th International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence (IJCAI)'', pages 2456–2461, Hyderabad.</ref><ref>C Gardent, K Striegnitz (2007). Generating bridging definite descriptions. In H Bunt, Reinhard Muskens, editors, ''Computing Meaning, Volume 3. Studies in Linguistics and Philosophy.'' Springer Publishers, pages 369–396, Berlin, DB.</ref><ref>C Areces, A Koller, K Striegnitz (2008). Referring expressions as formulas of Description Logic. ''Proceedings of the 5th International Natural Language Generation Conference (INLG)'', pages 42–49, Salt Fork, OH.</ref> <ref group=note name="Krahmer&van Deemter" />
==Problem definition== Dale and Reiter (1995) think about referring expressions as distinguishing descriptions.
They define: * The ''referent'' as the entity that should be described * The ''context set'' as set of salient entities * The ''contrast set'' or ''potential distractors'' as all elements of the context set except the referent * A ''property'' as a reference to a single [[attribute-value pair]] Each entity in the domain can be characterised as a set of [[attribute-value pair]]s for example <math>\langle</math>type, dog<math>\rangle</math>, <math>\langle</math>gender, female<math>\rangle</math> or <math>\langle</math>age, 10 years<math>\rangle</math>.
The problem then is defined as follows:
Let <math>r</math> be the intended referent, and <math>C</math> be the contrast set. Then, a set <math>L</math> of attribute–value pairs will represent a distinguishing description if the following two conditions hold: # Every attribute–value pair in <math>L</math> applies to <math>r</math>: that is, every element of <math>L</math> specifies an attribute–value that <math>r</math> possesses. # For every member <math>c</math> of <math>C</math>, there is at least one element <math>l</math> of <math>L</math> that does not apply to <math>c</math>: that is, there is an <math>l</math> in <math>L</math> that specifies an attribute–value that <math>c</math> does not possess. <math>l</math> is said to rule out <math>c</math>. In other words, to generate a referring expression one is looking for a set of properties that apply to the referent but not to the distractors.<ref name="Dale&Reiter" />
The problem could be easily solved by conjoining all the properties of the referent which often leads to long descriptions violating the second [[Gricean maxim#Maxim of Quantity|Gricean Maxim of Quantity]]. Another approach would be to find the shortest distinguishing description like the [[#Full Brevity|Full Brevity algorithm]] does. Yet in practice it is most common to instead include the condition that referring expressions produced by an algorithm should be as similar to human-produced ones as possible although this is often not explicitly mentioned.<ref group=note name="Krahmer&van Deemter" />
==Basic algorithms==
===Full Brevity=== The Full Brevity algorithm always finds a minimal distinguishing description meaning there is no shorter distinguishing description in regard to properties used.
Therefore, it iterates over <math>n=1,2,3,4,...</math> and checks every description of a length of <math>n</math> properties until a distinguishing description is found.
Two problems arise from this way of creating referring expressions. Firstly the algorithm has a high complexity meaning it is [[NP-hard]] which makes it impractical to use.<ref>M R Garey, D S. Johnson (1979). ''Computers and Intractability: A Guide to the Theory of NP–Completeness''. W. H. Freeman, New York.</ref> Secondly human speakers produce descriptions that are not minimal in many situations.<ref>D R Olson (1970). Language and thought: Aspects of a cognitive theory of semantics. ''Psychological Review'', 77:257–273.</ref><ref>S Sonnenschein (1984). The effect of redundant communication on listeners: Why different types may have different effects. ''Journal of Psycholinguistic Research'', 13:147–166.</ref><ref>T Pechmann (1989). Incremental speech production and referential overspecification. ''Linguistics'', 27:98–110.</ref><ref>P E Engelhardt, K G.D Bailey, F Ferreira (2006). Do speakers and listeners observe the Gricean Maxim of Quantity?. ''Journal of Memory and Language'', 54:554–573.</ref><ref group=note name="Krahmer&van Deemter" />
===Greedy Heuristics=== The Greedy Heuristics algorithm<ref name="Dale1989"/><ref name="Dale1992"/> approximates the Full Brevity algorithm by iteratively adding the most distinguishing property to the description. The most distinguishing property means the property that rules out most of the remaining distractors. The Greedy Heuristics algorithm is more efficient than the Full Brevity algorithm.<ref group=note name="Krahmer&van Deemter" />
Dale and Reiter(1995)<ref name="Dale&Reiter"/> present the following algorithm for the Greedy Heuristic:
Let <math>L</math> be the set of properties to be realised in our description; let <math>P</math> be the set of properties known to be true of our intended referent <math>r</math> (we assume that <math>P</math> is non-empty); and let <math>C</math> be the set of distractors (the contrast set). The initial conditions are thus as follows: <math>C = \{ \langle </math>all distractors<math>\rangle \}</math>; <math>P = \{ \langle </math>all properties true of <math>r\rangle \}</math>; <math>L = \{\}</math>
In order to describe the intended referent <math>r</math> with respect to the contrast set <math>C</math>, we do the following: 1. Check Success: '''if''' <math>|C| = 0</math> '''then''' return <math>L</math> as a distinguishing description '''elseif''' <math>P = \empty</math> '''then''' fail '''else''' '''goto''' Step 2. 2. Choose Property: '''for each''' <math>p_i \in P</math> '''do''': <math>C_i \leftarrow C \cap \{x|p_i(x)\}</math> Chosen property is <math>p_j</math> , where <math>C_j</math> is the smallest set. '''goto''' Step 3. 3. Extend Description (wrt the chosen <math>p_j</math>): <math>L \leftarrow L \cup \{p_j\}</math> <math>C \leftarrow C_j</math> <math>P \leftarrow P - \{p_j\}</math> '''goto''' Step 1.
===Incremental Algorithm=== The Incremental Algorithm (IA) by Dale and Reiter<ref name="Dale&Reiter"/> was the most influential algorithm before 2000. It is based on the idea of a ''preferential'' order of attributes or properties that speakers go by. So in order to run the Incremental Algorithm, first a preference order of attributes has to be given. Now the algorithm follows that order and adds those properties to the description which rule out any remaining distractors. Furthermore, Dale and Reiter<ref name="Dale&Reiter"/> stress the attribute type which is always included in their descriptions even if it does not rule out any distractors.
Also the type values are part of a ''subsumption hierarchy'' including some ''basic level values''. For example, in the ''pet'' domain ''chihuahua'' is subsumed by ''dog'' and ''dog'' by ''animal''. Because ''dog'' is defined as a basic level ''dog'' would be preferred by the algorithms, if ''chihuahua'' does not rule out any distractors.
The Incremental Algorithm is easy to implement and also computationally efficient running in [[polynomial time]]. The description generated by the IA can contain redundant properties that are superfluous because of later added properties. The creators do not consider this as a weakness, but rather as making the expressions less "psycholinguistically implausible".<ref name="Dale&Reiter" />
The following algorithm is a simplified version of Dale and Reiter’s Incremental Algorithm<ref name="Dale&Reiter"/> by Krahmer and van Deemter<ref name="Krahmer&van Deemter"/> that takes as input the referent ''r'', the ''D'' containing a collection of domain objects and a domain-specific ordered list ''Pref'' of preferred attributes. In the notation ''L'' is the description, ''C'' the context set of distractors and the function RulesOut({{angbr|A<sub>i</sub>, V}}) returns the set of objects which have a value different to V for attribute A<sub>i</sub>. IncrementalAlgorithm ({r}, D, Pref){ L ← ∅ C ← D - {r} '''for each''' A<sub>i</sub> in list Pref '''do''' V = Value(r, A<sub>i</sub>) '''if''' C ∩ RulesOut({{angbr|A<sub>i</sub>, V}}) ≠ ∅ '''then''' L ← L ∪ {{{angbr|A<sub>i</sub>, V}}} C ← C - RulesOut({{angbr|A<sub>i</sub>, V}}) '''endif''' '''if''' C ≠ ∅ '''then''' '''return''' L '''endif''' '''return''' failure }<ref group=note name="Krahmer&van Deemter" />
==Evaluation of REG systems== Before 2000 evaluation of REG systems has been of theoretical nature like the one done by Dale and Reiter.<ref name="Dale&Reiter"/> More recently, empirical studies have become popular which are mostly based on the assumption that the generated expressions should be similar to human-produced ones. [[Corpus linguistics|Corpus]]-based evaluation began quite late in REG due to a lack of suitable data sets. Still corpus-based evaluation is the most dominant method at the moment though there is also evaluation by human judgement.<ref group=note name="Krahmer&van Deemter" />
===Corpus-based evaluation=== First the distinction between [[text corpora]] and experimental corpora has to be made. [[Text corpora]] like the GNOME corpus<ref name="Poesio et al."/> can contain texts from all kind of domains. In REG they are used to evaluate the ''realization'' part of algorithms. The ''content selection'' part of REG on the other hand requires a corpus that contains the properties of all domain objects as well as the properties used in references. Typically those fully "semantically transparent"<ref>K van Deemter, I van der Sluis, A Gatt (2006). Building a semantically transparent corpus for the generation of referring expressions. ''In Proceedings of the 4th International Conference on Natural Language Generation (INLG)'', pages 130–132, Sydney.</ref> created in experiments using simple and controlled settings.
These experimental corpora once again can be separated into ''General-Purpose Corpora'' that were collected for another purpose but have been analysed for referring expressions and ''Dedicated Corpora'' that focus specifically on referring expressions. Examples of General-Purpose Corpora are the Pear Stories,<ref>W W Chafe (1980). ''The Pear Stories: Cognitive, Cultural, and Linguistic Aspects of Narrative Production.'' Ablex, Norwood, NJ.</ref> the Map Task corpus<ref>A A Anderson, M Bader, E Gurman Bard, E Boyle, G Doherty, S Garrod, S Isard, J Kowtko, J McAllister, J Miller, C Sotillo, H Thompson, R Weinert (1991). The HCRC map task corpus. ''Language and Speech'', 34:351–366.</ref> or the Coconut corpus<ref>B Di Eugenio, P W Jordan, R H Thomason, J D Moore (2000). The agreement process: an empirical investigation of human–human computer-mediated collaborative dialogs. ''International Journal of Human–Computer Studies'', 53:1017–1076.</ref> while the Bishop corpus,<ref>P Gorniak, D Roy (2004). Grounded semantic composition for visual scenes. ''Journal of Artificial Intelligence Research'', 21:429–470.</ref> the Drawer corpus<ref>J Viethen, R Dale (2006). Algorithms for generating referring expressions: Do they do what people do?. ''Proceedings of the 4th International Conference on Natural Language Generation (INLG)'', pages 63–70, Sydney.</ref> and the TUNA corpus<ref name="Gatt Sluis Deemter">A Gatt, I van der Sluis, K van Deemter (2007). Evaluating algorithms for the generation of referring expressions using a balanced corpus. ''Proceedings of the 11th European Workshop on Natural Language Generation (ENLG)'', pages 49–56, Schloss Dagstuhl.</ref> count to the Dedicated Corpora. The TUNA corpus which contains web-collected data on the two domains furniture and people has been used in three shared REG challenges already.<ref group=note name="Krahmer&van Deemter" />
===Evaluation metrics=== To measure the correspondence between corpora and the results of REG algorithms several Metrics have been developed.
To measure the ''content selection'' part the [[Sørensen–Dice coefficient|Dice coefficient]]<ref>L R Dice (1945). Measures of the amount of ecologic association between species. ''Ecology'', 26:297–302.</ref> or the MASI (Measuring Agreement on Set-valued Items)<ref>R Passonneau (2006). Measuring agreement on set-valued items (MASI) for semantic and pragmatic annotation. ''Proceedings of the 5th International Conference on Language Resources and Evaluation (LREC)'', pages 831–836, Genoa.</ref> metric are used. These measure the overlap of properties in two descriptions. In an evaluation the scores are usually averaged over references made by different human participants in the corpus. Also sometimes a measure called Perfect Recall Percentage (PRP)<ref name="Gatt Sluis Deemter"/> or Accuracy<ref>A Gatt, A Belz, E Kow (2008). The TUNA challenge 2008: Overview and evaluation results. ''Proceedings of the 5th International Conference on Natural Language Generation (INLG)'', pages 198–206, Salt Fork, OH.</ref> is used which calculates the percentage of perfect matches between an algorithm-produced and a human-produced reference.
For the ''linguistic realization'' part of REG the overlap between strings has been measured using metrics like [[BLEU]]<ref>K Papineni, S Roukos, T Ward, W Zhu (2002). BLEU: A method for automatic evaluation of machine translation. ''Proceedings of the 40th Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics (ACL)'', pages 311–318, Philadelphia, PA.</ref> or [[NIST (metric)|NIST]].<ref>G Doddington (2002). Automatic evaluation of machine translation quality using n-gram co-occurrence statistics. ''Proceedings of the 2nd International Conference on Human Language Technology Research (HLT)'', pages 138–145, San Diego, CA.</ref> A problem that occurs with string-based metrics is that for example "The small monkey" is measured closer to "The small donkey" than to "The little monkey".
A more time consuming way to evaluate REG algorithms is by letting humans judge the ''Adequacy'' (How clear is the description?) and ''Fluency'' (Is the description given in good and clear English?) of the generated expression. Also Belz and Gatt<ref>A Belz, A Gatt (2008). Intrinsic vs. extrinsic evaluation measures for referring expression generation. ''Proceedings of the 46th Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics (ACL)'', Columbus, OH.</ref> evaluated referring expressions using an experimental setup. The participants get a generated description and then have to click on the target. Here the extrinsic metrics reading time, identification time and error rate could be evaluated. <ref group=note name="Krahmer&van Deemter" />
==Notes== {{Reflist|group=note}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox writer | name = Rongowhakaata Halbert | embed = | honorific_prefix = | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1894|02|02|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Gisborne, New Zealand|Gisborne]], New Zealand | death_date = {{Death date and age|1973|04|11|1894|02|02|df=y}} | death_place = [[Auckland]], New Zealand | resting_place = | occupation = Interpreter, historian, genealogist | language = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | period = | genre = <!-- or: | genres = --> | subject = Māori History | movement = | notablework = ''Horouta: The History of the Horouta Canoe, Gisborne and East Coast'' | spouse ={{marriage|Patehepa Tamatea|1915|1972|end=d.}} | partner = <!-- or: | partners = --> | children = | relatives = [[Wi Pere]] (grandfather) | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | years_active = | module = | portaldisp = <!-- "on", "yes", "true", etc; or omit --> }}
'''Rongowhakaata''' "'''Rongo'''" '''Pere Halbert''' (2 February 1894 – 11 April 1973) was a [[Māori people|Māori]] tribal leader, interpreter, historian and [[genealogist]]. He was considered "an eminent authority on Māori literature".<ref name="dnzb" /> Halbert's book ''Horouta: The History of the Horouta Canoe, Gisborne and East Coast'', published [[List of works published posthumously|posthumously]] in 1999, is considered a classic of tribal history.<ref name="Beattie"/>
==Early life== Halbert was born on 2 February 1894 in Waerenga-a-Hika, [[Gisborne, New Zealand|Gisborne]], to Hetekia Te Kani Pere (or Halbert), a farmer, and his wife, Riripeti Rangikohera Ranginui. His grandfather was noted Māori politician [[Wi Pere]]. Halbert attended school in Gisborne up until 1911. He then attended [[Nelson College]] from 1911 to 1914, where he was a [[prefect]] and excelled at sports and music.<ref name="dnzb"/>
On 11 September 1915, he married Patehepa Tamatea and together they had seven children. For a time they ran a dairy farm at Pukepapa, near Waituhi.<ref name="dnzb" />
==Career==
Halbert became a licensed interpreter in 1915.<ref name="pbh-interpeting"/> His strong command of the [[Māori language]] combined with his knowledge of Māori literature gained him important roles such as assisting the [[New Zealand Geographic Board]] with Māori place names, and revising the sixth edition of H. W. Williams's Māori dictionary. Later he acted as an adviser on Māori texts for the [[Polynesian Society]]. Halbert was a founding member of the Gisborne Art Gallery and Museum in 1955, and the first chairman of the Maori Museum Committee, advising on the Māori collections.<ref name="dnzb" />
As a historian and genealogist, Halbert contributed to John Hikawera Mitchell's ''Takitimu'' (1944), a record of the migration of the [[Ngati Kahungunu]].<ref name="takitimu"/> He also contributed to the Whakatane and District Historical Society's first memoir, ''Te Tini o Toi'', as well as papers on the dating of Maori genealogies.<ref name="dnzb" />
From 1940 onwards Halbert devoted most of his time to studying the history and genealogy of the East Coast [[iwi]].<ref name="dnzb" /> In 1999 his book ''Horouta: The History of the Horouta Canoe, Gisborne and East Coast'' was posthumously published by [[Reed Publishing]].<ref name="Beattie" />
Poor health forced Halbert's retirement from the Maori Purposes Fund Board in 1968. He died at Lavington Private Hospital in [[Epsom, New Zealand|Epsom]], Auckland on 11 April 1973 and was buried at Taruheru Cemetery in Gisborne. He was survived by three daughters and three sons.<ref name="dnzb" />
At the time of his death, Halbert was preparing a major historical and genealogical work. He left three main collections of papers: a manuscript called 'Horouta', 130 complete [[whakapapa]] charts, and a series of maps and historical data with iwi and [[hapū]].<ref name="dnzb" />
==Publications== * ''Te Tini o Toi'' (September 1961) * ''Horouta: The History of the Horouta Canoe, Gisborne and East Coast'' (1999)
==References== {{Reflist|2|refs= <ref name="dnzb">{{DNZB|title=Rongowhakaata Pere Halbert|first=Peter|last=Gordon|id=4h4|accessdate=23 April 2017}}</ref> <ref name="pbh-interpeting">{{cite news|title=Poverty Bay Herald|url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/PBH19150713.2.7|accessdate=6 May 2017|issue=13734|publisher=Papers Past|date=13 July 1915}}</ref> <ref name="Beattie">{{cite web|last1=Beattie|first1=Graham|title=Horouta: The History of the Horouta Canoe, Gisborne and East Coast|url=http://beattiesbookblog.blogspot.co.nz/2012/11/horouta-history-of-horouta-canoe.html|accessdate=21 June 2015}}</ref> <ref name="takitimu">{{cite book|author1=Tiaki Hikawera Mitira|title=Takitimu|date=1972|publisher=Reed Publishing (NZ) Ltd|location=Wellington|page=268|url=http://nzetc.victoria.ac.nz/tm/scholarly/tei-MitTaki-t1-back-d1-d7-d3.html#name-208124-mention}}</ref> }}

revision.text:
{{for|the project to land a probe on comet 67P|Rosetta (spacecraft)}} {{Infobox project | name = Rosetta Project | logo = | image = Rosetta disk.jpg | caption = One goal of the project is the three-inch nickel [[HD-Rosetta|Rosetta Disk]], on which will be etched 13,000 [[microscopic]] pages of text. | mission_statement = The Rosetta Project is a global collaboration of language specialists and native speakers working to build a publicly accessible digital library of human languages. | commercial = No | type = Archival of human languages | products = [[HD-Rosetta|Rosetta Disk]] | established = <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | disestablished = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | current_status = Active }}
The '''Rosetta Project''' is a global collaboration of language specialists and native speakers working to develop a contemporary version of the historic [[Rosetta Stone]] to last from 2000 to [[Timeline of the far future#Technology and culture|12,000]] AD; it is run by the [[Long Now Foundation]]. Its goal is a meaningful survey and near permanent archive of 1,500 [[language]]s. Some of these languages have fewer than one thousand speakers left. Others are considered to be dying out because government centralization and [[globalization]] are increasing the prevalence of [[English language|English]] and other major languages. The intention is to create a unique platform for [[comparative linguistics|comparative linguistic]] research and education, as well as a functional linguistic tool that might help in the recovery or revitalisation of lost languages in the future.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/linguafranca/2012-03-24/3903626 The Rosetta Project], Presented by Maria Zijlstra on Lingua Franca, 24 March 2012, ABC Radio National (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)</ref><ref>[http://blog.longnow.org/02011/03/07/dr-laura-welcher-the-rosetta-project-the-language-commons/ Dr. Laura Welcher – The Rosetta Project & The Language Commons], March 7th, 2011, by Austin Brown, Blog of the Long Now</ref>
The project is creating this broad language archive through an open contribution, open review process similar to the strategy that created the original ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]''. The resulting archive will be publicly available in three different media: a [[HD-Rosetta]] micro-etched [[nickel]] [[alloy]] disc three inches (7.62 cm) across with a 2,000 year life expectancy; a single volume monumental reference book; and a growing online archive. <!-- I thought the metal was going to be [[Monel]]; did they change it, or did whoever write this not know the name/that we have an article on it? -->
==Concept== [[File:World population spoken languages.svg|thumb|200px|Fifty to ninety percent of the world's languages (in red) are predicted to disappear in the next century]]
Fifty to ninety percent of the world's languages are predicted to disappear in the next century, many with little or no significant documentation. {{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} Much linguistic description, especially the description of languages with few speakers, remains hidden in personal research files or poorly preserved in under-funded archives.
As part of the effort to secure this critical legacy of linguistic diversity, the Long Now Foundation plans a broad online survey and near-permanent physical archive of 1,500 of the approximately 7,000 human languages.
The project has three overlapping goals:
# to create an unprecedented platform for comparative linguistic research and education # to develop and widely distribute a functional linguistic tool that might help with the recovery of lost or compromised languages in unknown futures # to offer an aesthetic object that suggests the immense diversity of human languages as well as the very real threats to the continued survival of this diversity
The 1,500-language [[corpus linguistics | corpus]] expands on the parallel-text structure of the original Rosetta Stone through archiving ten descriptive components for each of the 1,500 selected languages.
The goal is an [[Open-source software|open source]] "[[Linux]] of [[Linguistics]]"—an effort of collaborative online scholarship drawing on the expertise and contributions of thousands of academic specialists and native speakers around the world. The project is also organising formal archive research groups at [[Stanford University|Stanford]], [[Yale University|Yale]], [[University of California, Berkeley|Berkeley]], the American [[Library of Congress]], and the American [[SIL International|Summer Institute of Linguistics]] (and its offices in [[Dallas]]).
The resulting Rosetta archives are publicly available in three different media:
# a free and continually growing online archive, also available as a DVD;<ref>{{cite web |title=Interactive Disk |url=https://rosettaproject.org/disk/interactive/ |website=Rosettaproject.org |accessdate=12 June 2018}}</ref> # a single-volume monumental reference book;{{cn|date=June 2018}} # an extreme-longevity micro-etched disc.
A "Version 1.0" of the [[HD-Rosetta]] disc was completed on November 3, 2008.<ref>[http://blog.longnow.org/2008/11/03/macro-to-micro-etching/ Macro to micro etching], November 3rd, 2008, by Alexander Rose, The Long Now Foundation's Blog</ref> The disc contains over 13,000 pages of information using over 1,500 languages,<ref name="weardisk"/> which can be read after magnifying by 650 times with a microscope.
In early 2017, the Rosetta Wearable Disk was released.<ref name="Smithsonian">{{cite web |last1=Blakemore |first1=Erin |title=This Necklace Contains All of the World’s Languages |url=https://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/necklace-contains-all-worlds-languages-180961876/ |website=Smithsonian.com (Smart News) |publisher=Smithsonian |accessdate=12 June 2018}}</ref> It was developed using a similar manufacturing process as the first edition of the Rosetta Disk, the main difference being that the final archive is about 2 cm in diameter, thus enabling wearing as an ornament on the human body. One side has instructions in eight different languages and scripts (Bahasa Indonesia, English, Hindi, Mandarin, Modern Standard Arabic, Spanish, Swahili, and Russian), and the other an archive of over 1000 human languages assembled in 2016. By November 2017, the initial run of 100 disks had all been sold, but new releases are planned.<ref name="weardisk">{{cite web |title=Rosetta Wearable Disk |url=https://rosettaproject.org/disk/wearable/ |website=The Rosetta Project: A Long Now Foundation Library of Human Language |accessdate=12 June 2018}}</ref>
==See also== * [[All Species Foundation]], another project of the foundation * [[Intercontinental Dictionary Series]] * [[Endangered language]] * [[Language death]] * [[Language revitalization]] * [[Time capsule]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Spoken Wikipedia|Rosetta_Project.ogg|2006-07-15}} * {{Official website|www.rosettaproject.org}} * Dan Farber, [https://web.archive.org/web/20051216072752/http://blogs.zdnet.com/BTL/?p=1443 "The Rosetta Project: Rescuing languages"], [[ZDNet]] May 25, 2005 [https://web.archive.org/web/20051216072752/http://blogs.zdnet.com/BTL/?p=1443 Archived copy] * [http://www.vimeo.com/43530099 Rosetta Project film] * {{Internet Archive|rosettaproject}}

[[Image:SemiticMuseumHarvard.jpg|thumb|250px|right|The Harvard Semitic Museum]] The Harvard Semitic Museum was founded in 1889, and moved into its present location at 6 Divinity Avenue in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]], in 1903.
From the beginning, it was the home of the Department of Near Eastern Languages and Civilizations, a departmental library, a repository for research collections, a public educational institute, and a center for archaeological exploration. Among the museum's early achievements were the first scientific excavations in [[the Holy Land]] (at [[Samaria]] in 1907–1912) and excavations at [[Nuzi]] and Tell el-Khaleifeh in the [[Sinai]], where the earliest alphabet was found.
The museum's artifacts include [[pottery]], [[cylinder seal]]s, [[sculpture]], [[coin]]s, [[clay tablet|cuneiform tablet]]s, and Egyptian [[mummy]] [[sarcophagi]]. Many are from museum-sponsored excavations in [[Jordan]], [[Iraq]], [[Egypt]], [[Cyprus]], [[Israel]], and [[Tunisia]]. The museum holds plaster casts of the [[Black Obelisk of Shalmaneser III]], the [[Laws of Hammurabi]], and the [[Victory stele of Esarhaddon|Stele of Esarhaddon]], as well as a full-scale model of an [[Iron Age]] [[Israelite]] house. The museum is dedicated to the use of these collections for the teaching, research, and publication of Near Eastern archaeology, history, and culture.
==History== Architectural firm A. W. Longfellow broke ground on the present Harvard Semitic Museum site on September 27, 1900. Construction was completed in spring of 1902, and the public portions of the museum were opened on February 5, 1903.<ref>{{cite book|last=Weissman|first=Ann Waymire|title=Governance and the Academic Museum: A Case History of the Semitic Museum|year=2012|publisher=Harvard Extension School|location=Cambridge, MA|page=22|type=Thesis|chapter=Chapter 3}}</ref>
The museum's facilities were repurposed during World War II, and it was closed to the public from August 1942 through April 1946. Twelve years later it was closed again to the public, lasting from 1958 through 1982.
The museum reopened in April 1982, and then Harvard President Derek Bok spoke at the reopening ceremony.<ref>{{cite book|last=Weissman|first=Ann Waymire|title=Governance and the Academic Museum: A Case History of the Semitic Museum|year=2012|publisher=Harvard Extension School|location=Cambridge, MA|page=50|type=Thesis|chapter=Chapter 4}}</ref> In December 2012, Harvard announced a new consortium, the Harvard Museums of Science and Culture, whose members are the [[Harvard Museum of Natural History]], the Harvard Semitic Museum, the [[Peabody Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology]], and the [[Collection of Historical Scientific Instruments]].
==Functions== ===Exhibition and education=== The Semitic Museum, through the collaborative efforts of departmental faculty, curators, museum curatorial staff, and students; mounts exhibits, often in conjunction with university courses, which not only serve the university community, but also attract the general public. The museum has an active public outreach program featuring tours for school groups and teacher training workshops. The museum also sponsors, either alone or in conjunction with other institutions, a number of public lectures each year. Through these educational efforts, the museum seeks to promote a wider understanding of the civilizations of the Near East and their great cultural legacies.<ref>{{cite web|last=Semitic Museum|title=About|url=http://www.semiticmuseum.fas.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do?keyword=k66717&tabgroupid=icb.tabgroup105529|work=Semitic Museum Website|publisher=President and Fellows of Harvard College|accessdate=22 June 2012}}</ref>
===Teaching with the collection=== There are many opportunities for Harvard University students and faculty to make use of the museum collections and facilities. Objects can be used for coursework, viewing assignments, research papers, senior theses, dissertations, and teaching displays. The basement seminar room is available for sections scheduled to view the collection.<ref>{{cite web|last=Semitic Museum|title=About|url=http://www.semiticmuseum.fas.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do?keyword=k66717&tabgroupid=icb.tabgroup105529|work=Semitic Museum Website|publisher=President and Fellows of Harvard] College|accessdate=22 June 2012}}</ref>
===Research and publication=== The Harvard Semitic Museum sponsors archaeological field research into the complex societies of the Near East, with special emphasis on those ancient cultures related to the world of the Bible. Each year more than 100 staff, students, and volunteers participate in the Ashkelon Excavations (The Leon Levy Expedition), led by Honorary Museum Director Lawrence E. Stager, Dr. Daniel M. Master, and Dr. Adam Aja. The museum, through its Harvard Semitic Series and Harvard Semitic Monographs, publishes archaeological, historical, philological, and cultural studies of the Near East, many of which present the research of the department faculty and their students.<ref>{{cite web|last=Semitic Museum|title=About|url=http://www.semiticmuseum.fas.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do?keyword=k66717&tabgroupid=icb.tabgroup105529|work=Semitic Museum Website|publisher=President and Fellows of Harvard College|accessdate=22 June 2012}}</ref>
==External links== * [http://www.semiticmuseum.fas.harvard.edu Semitic Museum official site] * [http://www.nelc.fas.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do Department of Near Eastern Languages and Civilizations at Harvard]
